title: 111_hr2110
content: The Act is titled the "Mobile Workforce State Income Tax Fairness and Simplification Act" and limits state withholding and taxation of employee income. The "Mobile Workforce State Income Tax Fairness and Simplification Act" limits state income tax to the employee's residence state and the state where they work for more than 30 days in a calendar year. Wages are only subject to state income tax withholding if the employee meets the criteria outlined in the Act. The Act limits state income tax to the employee's residence state and the state where they work for more than 30 days in a calendar year. Income tax withholding and reporting apply to wages earned as of the commencement date of duties in the State during the calendar year. Employers can rely on an employee's time estimate for state income tax obligations unless there is fraud or collusion to evade tax. The Act allows employers to rely on an employee's time estimate for state income tax obligations unless there is fraud or collusion to evade tax. Records maintained by the employer for other business purposes do not override this, but employers can use a time and attendance system to track employee locations instead. The Act allows employers to use a time and attendance system to track employee locations for state income tax obligations, overriding the employee's own determination. If an employee performs duties in multiple states in one day, they will be considered to have performed in the resident state. The Act allows employers to track employee locations for state income tax obligations. If an employee works in multiple states in one day, they will be considered to have worked in the nonresident state. The term "employee" is defined by the state where duties are performed, excluding professional athletes. Transit time does not count towards determining the location of employment duties. The term "employee" is defined by the state where duties are performed, excluding professional athletes and entertainers. Professional athletes are individuals who perform services in professional athletic events, while professional entertainers perform in the performing arts for wages or other remuneration. The term "certain public figures" refers to prominent individuals who provide services for wages on a per-event basis, such as speeches or personal appearances. The term "figures" refers to individuals who provide services for wages on a per-event basis, such as speeches or personal appearances. The term "employer" is defined as per section 3401(d) of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 or by the State where duties are performed. "State" refers to each of the several States of the United States. "Time and attendance system" is a system where employees record their work location daily when working outside their state. The term "wages or other remuneration" is defined by the State where employment duties are performed. The Act will be effective starting January 1, 2011.
